discussion.content:
The Answer is C.

This is a SaaS provider, they handle the application side and the error only happens when the browser is updated to a newer version. This means the provider is not keeping up with the updates or the changes in technology (application, OS, Infrastructure..)

Selected Answer: C
C, because the problem only occours only when upgrading the browser and disappears when rolling back. Probably the upgraded browser has a different minimum recommended SSL version, so it gives a warning to the user.
The answer is A. Can someone explain why it is? I saw a practice exam with this same question, the test taker chose A and got %100 correct at the end.

comments.content: No way it is A. The expired SSL certificate would not stop you from going to the website, it would simply give you a warning about it. Older browsers will use obsolete protocols that allow you to go to older sites, so I believe it is still C. Maybe the test they took was misinformed?

questions.question_text: A new browser version has been deployed to all users at a company. After the deployment, users report that they can no longer access the company's secure time-card system, which is hosted by a SaaS provider. A technician investigates and discovers a security error is received upon opening the site. If the browser is rolled back to the older version, the site is accessible again. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the security error users are seeing?

choices.B: Federation issues between the SaaS provider and the company
choices.C: Obsolete security technologies implemented on the SaaS servers
choices.D: Unencrypted communications between the users and the application
choices.A: SSL certificate expiration on the SaaS load balancers

questions.answer_description: Can't be a firewall issue, or the old delivery controller would have a license error as well. Based on the information given, I would say they are not licensed for clustering.

choices.A: A firewall is blocking the port on the license server.
choices.C: The existing license is not supported for clusters.
choices.B: The existing license is for a lower version.

comments.content: I would say because firewall rules are IP specific in most cases that I have experienced, so the new server may not have the appropriate rules set for that host's IP.

discussion.content:
I think C is correct. 
I think A is wrong because the port wasnt blocked before why would it be blocked now?

Going with B.

C. a license for clusters? yet it work for the older delivery controller?..
A. Firewall blocks the license server? so what's the point of having a license server if it's going to need 2 of them...

comments.content:
Also take note of what the question is asking:
"the NEW delivery controller returns an error"

It's 100% B.

discussion.content: Righ answer is B

comments.content: yes, because the old version works while the new one does not

discussion.content: I say C, the port being blocked was not an issue before.

comments.content: It wasn't an issue for the original hosts source IP.. this is a new host with new IP. I don't open firewall rules for my whole server subnet.

discussion.content:
Cluster = multiple computers
Cluster = required cloud friendly.
Seems the controller is sending the error because lic are not cluster / cloud friendly.
Answer is C
A. A firewall is blocking the port on the license server.
Answer is C
I think the answer is C
Answer is A

questions.question_text: A cloud architect created a new delivery controller for a large VM farm to scale up according to organizational needs. The old and new delivery controllers now form a cluster. However, the new delivery controller returns an error when entering the license code. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

discussion.content: I think it should be D, the only term that is related to CPU.

questions.question_text: A company is implementing a SaaS solution with a large user base. SaaS solution licensing is user based, and user management is critical to keep the cost in check. Which of the following is the MOST efficient way to meet this requirement?

discussion.content: there is a similar question but that answer is C. I doubt user will never inform admin if they do not need the account.

comments.content: sorry, question 2e is similar but the answer logic is different

discussion.content: b Daily >weekly
Running a script sounds more efficient, D
I do not think the SaaS provider would keep track of user activity. I say B.
B just feels most efficient
Answer should be B

choices.B: Have a nightly upload to the SaaS provider of the current user base based on API call.
choices.A: Have the administrator of the SaaS solution keep track of user activities.
choices.D: Have a weekly user management script maintain the SaaS user base.
choices.C: Have users remove their SaaS accounts when they no longer need the service.

choices.A: The development team is not looking at the correct server when querying for the logs.
choices.B: The security team has greater permissions than the development team.
choices.C: The audit logging service has been disabled on the server.
choices.D: The development team's syslog server is configured to listen on the wrong port.

questions.question_text: A cloud administrator updates the syslog forwarder configuration on a local server in production to use a different port. The development team is no longer receiving the audit logs from that server. However, the security team can retrieve and search the logs for the same server. Which of the following is MOST likely the issue?

discussion.content: Answer is D
Answer is:D
D. the Development team is not receiving the logs, suggesting the port config is the issue.
